questions.question: What is the CSS cascade?
questions.answer: The set of rules CSS uses to resolve conflicts between declarations: importance (!important), origin (user/author/UA), specificity, and source order.

questions.question: How is selector specificity typically ranked?
questions.answer: Inline styles > IDs > classes/attributes/pseudo-classes > elements/pseudo-elements.

questions.question: Does !important always win?
questions.answer: It wins within the same origin/importance level; conflicts between !important rules are still resolved by specificity and source order.

questions.question: What is inheritance in CSS?
questions.answer: Some properties (like color and font) inherit from parent to child; others (like margin) do not.

questions.question: What is the initial value of a CSS property?
questions.answer: The default value defined by CSS specs when no other value applies.

questions.question: What does box-sizing: content-box mean?
questions.answer: Width/height apply to the content only; padding and border add to the final rendered size.

questions.question: What does box-sizing: border-box mean?
questions.answer: Width/height include padding and border, making layout sizing more predictable.

questions.question: How do margin collapsing rules work (in simple terms)?
questions.answer: Vertical margins between block elements can collapse into a single margin (usually the larger one).

questions.question: What’s the difference between a block and an inline element?
questions.answer: Block elements start on a new line and can have width/height; inline elements flow in text and ignore width/height by default.

questions.question: What does display: inline-block do?
questions.answer: It flows inline like text but supports width/height like a block.

questions.question: What is the difference between visibility: hidden and opacity: 0?
questions.answer: Both hide visually, but visibility:hidden prevents interaction while opacity:0 can still be clickable unless pointer-events is changed.

questions.question: What does pointer-events: none do?
questions.answer: Prevents the element from receiving mouse/pointer interactions.

questions.question: What does the universal selector (*) select?
questions.answer: All elements.

questions.question: What are attribute selectors used for?
questions.answer: To target elements based on attributes (e.g., input[type='email']).

questions.question: What is the difference between :nth-child and :nth-of-type?
questions.answer: :nth-child counts all children; :nth-of-type counts only siblings of the same element type.

questions.question: What is the difference between ::before and :before?
questions.answer: They are equivalent in most browsers, but ::before is the modern pseudo-element syntax.

questions.question: When does z-index apply?
questions.answer: Primarily on positioned elements (or flex/grid items in certain cases) within a stacking context.

questions.question: What creates a new stacking context?
questions.answer: Examples: position with z-index, opacity < 1, transform, filter, isolation:isolate, and others.

questions.question: What is the difference between rem and em?
questions.answer: rem is relative to the root font-size; em is relative to the element’s computed font-size (often the parent).

questions.question: What’s a common reason to prefer rem for spacing?
questions.answer: It scales consistently with user font-size settings and avoids compounding in nested elements.

questions.question: What is the main axis in flexbox?
questions.answer: The axis along which flex items are laid out; it’s controlled by flex-direction.

questions.question: What is the cross axis in flexbox?
questions.answer: The axis perpendicular to the main axis.

questions.question: What does justify-content control in a flex container?
questions.answer: Distribution and alignment of items along the main axis.

questions.question: What does align-items control in a flex container?
questions.answer: Alignment of items along the cross axis for the whole line.

questions.question: What does align-self do?
questions.answer: Overrides align-items for a single flex/grid item.

questions.question: What does flex: 1 mean?
questions.answer: Shorthand for flex-grow: 1, flex-shrink: 1, flex-basis: 0% (commonly), allowing the item to grow and share remaining space.

questions.question: What does flex-basis control?
questions.answer: The initial main-size of a flex item before free space is distributed.

questions.question: What problem does gap solve in flex/grid layouts?
questions.answer: It creates consistent spacing between items without needing margins and avoiding edge-case math.

questions.question: How do you create a two-column layout with CSS Grid?
questions.answer: Use display:grid and grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr (or other fractions).

questions.question: What is the difference between auto-fill and auto-fit in CSS Grid?
questions.answer: Both repeat tracks, but auto-fit collapses empty tracks to fit content, while auto-fill keeps the track slots reserved.

questions.question: What is an implicit grid?
questions.answer: Grid tracks created automatically when items are placed outside the explicit grid defined by grid-template-rows/columns.

questions.question: What’s the difference between position: relative and position: absolute?
questions.answer: relative offsets the element from its normal position; absolute removes it from flow and positions it relative to the nearest positioned ancestor.

questions.question: What does position: sticky do?
questions.answer: It behaves like relative until a scroll threshold, then sticks like fixed within its scroll container.

questions.question: How do you center an element horizontally with margin?
questions.answer: Give it a width and use margin-left/right: auto (e.g., margin: 0 auto).

questions.question: How do you avoid layout shift when loading images?
questions.answer: Reserve space using width/height or an aspect-ratio box, so the page doesn’t reflow.

questions.question: What does aspect-ratio do?
questions.answer: Provides an intrinsic ratio used for sizing, often to maintain consistent boxes.

questions.question: What is a containing block?
questions.answer: The reference box used for percentage-based sizing and for positioning absolutely positioned elements.

questions.question: What does overflow: auto do?
questions.answer: Adds scrollbars only when content overflows.

questions.question: What is the difference between overflow-x and overflow-y?
questions.answer: They control overflow behavior independently on the horizontal and vertical axes.

questions.question: What is a common cause of “flex items not shrinking”?
questions.answer: Items can overflow because min-width defaults to auto; setting min-width: 0 on children often fixes it.

questions.question: What is a media query?
questions.answer: A CSS technique to apply styles based on device/viewport characteristics like width, resolution, or prefers-color-scheme.

questions.question: What is mobile-first CSS?
questions.answer: Write base styles for small screens first, then use min-width media queries to enhance for larger screens.

questions.question: What does @media (min-width: 768px) mean?
questions.answer: Apply the enclosed styles when the viewport width is at least 768px.

questions.question: What is the difference between px and viewport units (vw/vh)?
questions.answer: px is fixed; vw/vh are relative to the viewport dimensions.

questions.question: What are container queries (high level)?
questions.answer: They let styles respond to the size of a container rather than the viewport.

questions.question: Why are rem units helpful for accessibility?
questions.answer: They respect user font scaling, making layouts and typography easier to enlarge.

questions.question: What is prefers-reduced-motion used for?
questions.answer: To reduce or disable animations/transitions for users who request less motion.

questions.question: What is prefers-color-scheme used for?
questions.answer: To apply light/dark theme styles based on the user’s OS setting.

questions.question: What does max-width: 100% on images do?
questions.answer: Prevents images from overflowing their containers on smaller screens.

questions.question: What is the difference between min(), max(), and clamp()?
questions.answer: They compute dynamic values: min picks the smallest, max picks the largest, clamp clamps between a min and max with a preferred value.

questions.question: Give an example of clamp() usage.
questions.answer: Responsive font size like font-size: clamp(1rem, 2vw + 0.5rem, 2rem).

questions.question: What is a breakpoint?
questions.answer: A viewport (or container) size at which layout or styling changes for better usability.

questions.question: What is the viewport meta tag used for?
questions.answer: On mobile, it controls layout viewport scaling; without it, responsive CSS can behave unexpectedly.

questions.question: What is a fluid layout?
questions.answer: A layout that adapts smoothly using relative units instead of fixed pixel widths.

questions.question: What is the difference between responsive and adaptive design?
questions.answer: Responsive continuously adapts; adaptive switches between discrete layouts at breakpoints.

questions.question: What does line-height control?
questions.answer: The height of each line of text, affecting readability and vertical rhythm.

questions.question: What is the difference between font-weight: 400 and 700?
questions.answer: 400 is normal weight; 700 is bold (assuming the font has those weights).

questions.question: What is a web-safe font?
questions.answer: A font likely installed on most systems (e.g., Arial), reducing dependency on downloads.

questions.question: What is the difference between hex and rgb colors?
questions.answer: Both represent colors; hex is base-16 notation (#RRGGBB) and rgb is functional notation (rgb(r,g,b)).

questions.question: What is HSL and why use it?
questions.answer: Hue/Saturation/Lightness; it’s often easier to tweak theme colors by adjusting lightness or saturation.

questions.question: What does currentColor mean?
questions.answer: It resolves to the element’s computed color value (useful for icons/borders).

questions.question: What does border-radius do?
questions.answer: Rounds corners of an element’s border box.

questions.question: How do box-shadow and drop-shadow differ?
questions.answer: box-shadow follows the box; filter: drop-shadow follows the alpha shape (useful for images/SVG).

questions.question: What is a CSS gradient?
questions.answer: A generated image (linear-gradient, radial-gradient) that can be used as a background.

questions.question: What does background-size: cover do?
questions.answer: Scales the background image to cover the container, possibly cropping.

questions.question: What’s the difference between outline and border?
questions.answer: Outline doesn’t take up space and doesn’t affect layout; border does.

questions.question: Why is :focus-visible useful?
questions.answer: It shows focus styles only when focus is likely from keyboard, reducing noisy outlines on mouse click.

questions.question: What is a CSS transition?
questions.answer: An animation between two states when a property changes (e.g., on hover).

questions.question: What properties are best to animate for performance?
questions.answer: transform and opacity (they often avoid layout and paint).

questions.question: What does transform: translateZ(0) sometimes do?
questions.answer: It can promote an element to its own layer on some browsers, potentially improving animation smoothness.

questions.question: What is a CSS keyframe animation?
questions.answer: An animation defined with @keyframes, controlling styles at different percentages over time.

questions.question: What does animation-fill-mode do?
questions.answer: Controls how styles apply before/after the animation (e.g., forwards keeps the final state).

questions.question: What is easing in transitions?
questions.answer: The timing function controlling acceleration/deceleration (e.g., ease-in-out, cubic-bezier).

questions.question: What is will-change used for?
questions.answer: Hints to the browser that an element will change, potentially optimizing rendering (use sparingly).

questions.question: What does the CSS property transform-origin do?
questions.answer: Sets the point around which transforms are applied.

questions.question: How do you disable animations for reduced motion?
questions.answer: Use @media (prefers-reduced-motion: reduce) to set animation: none and transition: none (or reduce durations).

questions.question: What are CSS custom properties (CSS variables)?
questions.answer: Variables defined like --primary: #... that can be reused with var(--primary) and participate in the cascade.

questions.question: How do CSS variables differ from Sass variables?
questions.answer: CSS variables exist at runtime and can change per scope; Sass variables are compile-time constants.

questions.question: What is calc() used for?
questions.answer: To compute values from mixed units (e.g., width: calc(100% - 2rem)).

questions.question: What is :is() used for?
questions.answer: To group selectors without increasing specificity too much (e.g., :is(h1,h2,h3)).

questions.question: What is :where() used for?
questions.answer: Like :is() but it has zero specificity, useful for low-specificity defaults.

questions.question: What is the :has() selector?
questions.answer: A relational selector that can style an element based on its descendants/children matching a selector (parent selector behavior).

questions.question: What is accent-color used for?
questions.answer: To theme form controls like checkboxes and radio buttons in supported browsers.

questions.question: What is scroll-behavior: smooth?
questions.answer: Enables smooth scrolling for anchor navigation (respect reduced motion preferences).

questions.question: What is object-fit used for?
questions.answer: Controls how replaced elements like images/videos fit their boxes (cover/contain).

questions.question: What does @layer do?
questions.answer: Defines cascade layers to control which groups of styles win regardless of source order.

questions.question: What is the difference between logical properties (margin-inline) and physical ones (margin-left)?
questions.answer: Logical properties adapt to writing direction and language, improving internationalization.

questions.question: Why should focus styles not be removed globally?
questions.answer: They’re essential for keyboard users; removing them harms accessibility.

questions.question: What is a common accessible approach to hiding text for screen readers only?
questions.answer: Use a visually-hidden utility (e.g., position absolute, 1px size, clipped) so it remains readable by assistive tech.

questions.question: What does aria-hidden="true" mean (conceptually)?
questions.answer: It hides an element from the accessibility tree; the element remains visually present.

questions.question: What is a common pitfall when styling form controls?
questions.answer: Breaking default focus/keyboard behaviors; also inconsistent rendering across browsers.

questions.question: Why is color contrast important?
questions.answer: Low contrast reduces readability, especially for users with visual impairments; WCAG defines minimum ratios.

categories.title: Related Tech: Sass, PostCSS, Tailwind, CSS Modules

questions.question: What is Sass/SCSS used for?
questions.answer: A preprocessor that adds variables, nesting, mixins, modules, and more, compiling down to CSS.

questions.question: What is PostCSS?
questions.answer: A tool to transform CSS with JavaScript plugins (e.g., autoprefixer, nesting, minification).

questions.question: What does Autoprefixer do?
questions.answer: Automatically adds vendor prefixes based on target browser support.

questions.question: What is Tailwind CSS?
questions.answer: A utility-first CSS framework where you compose styles by applying small utility classes.

questions.question: What are CSS Modules?
questions.answer: A build-time approach that scopes CSS class names locally to a component to avoid collisions.

questions.question: What is BEM naming and why use it?
questions.answer: Block__Element--Modifier; a convention to reduce ambiguity and keep CSS maintainable at scale.

questions.question: What is CSS-in-JS (high level)?
questions.answer: Styling approach where CSS is generated/managed in JavaScript (e.g., styled-components, emotion).

questions.question: What’s a common strategy to manage large CSS codebases?
questions.answer: Use design tokens (variables), consistent conventions (BEM), component scoping (CSS Modules), and limit specificity using layers/utilities.
